Award.AwardTitle: CIF:SMALL: Image Restoration via Bayesian Structured Sparse Coding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Image quality degradation is inevitable in various scientific and engineering applications such as biomedical/astronomical imaging and error-prone image communications. Physics-based solutions to fight against those adversary factors (e.g., sensor noise, optical blur and channel errors) are often too expensive; therefore it is highly desirable to develop computational alternatives to salvage those degraded images. Computationally efficient and high-quality image restoration algorithms could find a wide range of applications from energy-efficient sensing to more-affordable healthcare.

This research contains two components. First is to characterize both nonlocal invariance and local variation of images in a principled fashion. A new framework called Bayesian structured sparse coding will be developed to unify and extend several existing classes of models (e.g., wavelet-based and patch-based) for natural images. Second, the new theoretical framework will facilitate the invention of computationally efficient inference algorithms for image restoration applications. The ultimate objective along this line of research is to make the developed Bayesian image restoration algorithms not only theoretically optimal but also practically feasible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• Theory. We have developed a Bayesian structured sparsity model capable of characterizing both nonlocal invariance and local variation within image signals. The newly developed structured sparsity model unifies several classes of models (e.g., wavelet-based and patch-based) by providing a bilateral variance estimation interpretation of low-rank approximation. The key new insight lies in that both local and nonlocal neighbors can be exploited to better resolve the intensity uncertainty for some unknown pixel. Such perspective allows us to extend the classical Wiener filtering into a nonlocal framework, which supplies a principled approach toward the optimization of pach-based nonlocal image restoration techniques.     
  • Algorithms. We have developed computationally efficient Bayesian inference algorithms based on the developed structured sparsity models. Unlike previous Bayesian formulation that is often computationally demanding (e.g., involving Markov Chain Monte Carlo or Gibbs sampling), our algorithms leverage recent advances in the literature of large-scale convex optimization (e.g., Alternative Direction Multiplier and Augmented Lagrange Multiplier) into image restoration. When compared against previous state-of-the-art (e.g., post-BM3D methods), our algorithms not only achieve higher visual quality (both subjectively and objectively) but also keep the computational complexity modest (our current implementation is matlab-based; further speed optimization is still possible).
  • Applications. We have explored several novel applications of the developed image restoration algorithms including low-illumination imaging, color-guided depth recovery and semi-supervised image super-resolution. a) For low-illumination imaging, we have developed a blind image restoration algorithm to remove signal-dependent noise in high-ISO images. Our algorithm has been compared with several commercial software such as NeatImage and shown convincingly better results. b) For color-guided depth recovery, we have developed a hybrid local and nonlocal method capable of more faithfully recovering missing high-frequency structural details in super-resolved depth maps. Such color-guided depth super-resolution technique has a wide range of applications from depth-based image rendering to human computer interaction. c) For semi-supervised image super-resolution, we have further extended the proposed structured sparsity model by learning its model parameters from a small training set. Such semi-supervising learning approach has shown to effectively improve the performance of model-based SR at a small price of extra computational cost (parameter estimation usually only takes a fraction of total cost). 
  • Broader Impacts. This award has mainly supported the PhD study of a PhD student (Wentian Zhou) who has graduated in the summer of 2017. This award also partially supported the graduate student of a female student (Priyanka) and helped promote geographic diversity with the NSF program (WV is among one of the EPSCoR states).
